Award.AwardTitle: Studies in free probability in operator algebras and a free analogue of the Riemann sphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
Most of the PI's research will be motivated by the development of free probability theory and of its applications, and will deal especially with acquiring new analytic tools and with extensions of the framework of free probability. One main theme will be the noncommutative analogue of the Riemann sphere constructed by the PI and the fully matricial analytic functions on it. Work on this analytic machinery will aim at preparing it for use in operator-valued free probability and its applications to operator algebras, random multimatrix systems and some of the problems arising in connection with the analogue of entropy. Another theme will be the continuing phenomenon of new extensions of free probability parallling classical situations, like free extreme values and connections to free quantum groups.

Free probability theory is a noncommutative probability framework, where independence is modelled on free products instead of tensor products, which makes it suitable for dealing with variables with the highest degree of noncommutativity. The free analogue of the Riemann sphere in the proposal aims at giving to a basic complex analysis object the same highest degree of noncommutativity to be adapted to uses in free probability. In free probability theory the role of the Gauss law is held by the Wigner semicircle law and the framework is particularly well suited for dealing with the asymptotics of systems of random matrices as their size increases. Via random matrices free probability has applications to multi-user telecommunication systems in engineering and to certain mathematical models in physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Free probability is a probability theory adapted to variables with the highest degree of non-commutativity, which like quantum mechanical quantities are realized by Hilbert space operators. The theory has important applications to random matrices and to operator algebras. Via its connection to random matrices, free probability has found applications to certain models in physics and engineering.

The project dealt with studies related to free probability and operator algebras in several directions, ranging from analysis with noncommutative variables, to a new approach to certain operator theory problems with affinities to free probability and to extending the core of free probability theory.

The study of analysis on a highly non-commutative analogue of the Riemann sphere , examined various examples of sets and of functions which arise in this context. This study is still at a preliminary stage.

In another direction, I have worked on a class of algebras of operators on Hilbert space, which provided a new perspective on certain operator theory problems I had been interested in years ago. The problems concern almost normal operators, that is operators the commutator of which with their adjoint is a trace-class operator. My interest in these problems was, loosely, motivated on one hand by the occurrence of almost normal operators in free probability theory in connection with the analogue of entropy and on the other hand by renewed interest in an operator algebra approach to certain perturbation of operators questions, which I had developed, and which had found new uses in work of A. Connes. The paper I wrote on the algebras arising from the problems on almost normal operators has been accepted for publication in the Journal of Noncommutative Geometry.The paper shows that these algebras have certain remarkable properties and that the operator theory problems are closely related to questions about the K-theory of the algebras. One question about the algebras which arose in the paper has been solved and generalized in a short joint paper by J. Bourgain and myself, which is available as a preprint.

I have also spent time thinking about certain extensions of the core of free probability. This has been a prelude to the research I am carrying out at present under the successor of this grant about free probability for systems of noncommutative  random variables structured in two groups.

During the time of the award, I have continued running the Probabilistic Operator Algebra Seminar at UC Berkeley with the active participation of the two graduate students I am supervising. My students have made progress in the work towards their degree.

I have given lectures about my work at several conferences and a distinguished lecture series in 2011 at Indiana University. I have also been an organizer of conferences. In particular , I was an organizer of a 3 months program on Bialgebras in Free Probability at the Schroedinger Institute in 2011.
